abstract.p: Band Creed will perform at Blockbuster Sony Entertainment Center in Camden, NJ; photo (S)

block.p: Creed has enjoyed quite a career, especially considering its short three-year duration. The group came seemingly out of nowhere, scoring one hit after another with four No. 1 singles from its debut, ''My Own Prison.''
Creed's current song ''Higher,'' from the best-selling ''Human Clay,'' recently soared into the Top 10 as well.

Creed has enjoyed quite a career, especially considering its short three-year duration. The group came seemingly out of nowhere, scoring one hit after another with four No. 1 singles from its debut, ''My Own Prison.''
Creed's current song ''Higher,'' from the best-selling ''Human Clay,'' recently soared into the Top 10 as well.

While the band mixes the influences of the hard-driving clamorous rock of Stone Temple Pilots and Alice in Chains along with a slew of 1970's metal, there's an inherent melodiousness to what they do. Much of that has to do with the frontman Scott Stapp and his soaring baritone.

Mr. Stapp, who also co-writes the band's songs, didn't listen to rock until his late teens because of his strict Pentecostal upbringing, and he still brings a spiritual foundation to the band's hard-edged, arena-ready songs.

For a band that spent $6,000 on its best-selling debut album, performing two nights at the Blockbuster Sony Entertainment Center (Harbour Boulevard, Camden), isn't half bad. They will appear there Aug. 25 and 26 at 7:30 p.m.; (609) 365-1300.
Brian Marshall, founding member and bassist, announced last week he will be leaving the band. His replacement is Bret Hestla.
